title: Data Processing for In Situ Electron Tomography toward Unbiased Approach: Application to Metal Nanoparticle Sintering
content: In situ observation combined with electron tomography (ET), so called in situ ET [1], is an emerging advanced transmission electron microscopy (TEM) observation technique, providing fruitful insights for analyzing temporal evolution of nanoscale structure of nanomaterials under external stimuli. For metal nanoparticles (NPs), which are attracting attention because of their low sintering temperature compared to the bulk state, the in situ ET would be an essential method to characterize their sintering behavior in statistical manner since they are easy to aggregate. Up to this time, the observation itself has been enabled by the current TEM [2]. However, its characterization, such as identifying where interface between two particles is in neck growth evaluation, likely relies on human recognition/judgement so far. Establishing automated as well as objective data processing workflow is necessary for quantitatively characterizing many body systems. In this study, we developed an image processing pipeline for analyzing sintering behavior of Cu nanoparticles (NPs).
